title: How to Survive Family Holidays As a Vegetarian

steps.headline: Talk to your relatives in advance to find out which dishes you can eat.
steps.description: Not only will this give you an idea of how much food will be available to you, it’s also a gentle way to get your family thinking about vegetarian dishes. They may be open to making more veg-friendly dishes to accommodate your diet. Say, "I'm trying to decide on a dish to bring for Thanksgiving and wanted to see what everyone else is bringing. I'm a vegetarian, and I'm hoping to find out how many dishes I'll be able to eat." Don’t demand that people make a vegetarian meal, but it’s good to let them know you won’t be eating any meat dishes. Remind them you're a vegetarian before every holiday meal. It’s likely that people won’t think about your dietary choices in between the holidays.

steps.headline: Ask people to make simple recipe substitutions so side dishes are veg-friendly.
steps.description: Some common holiday side dishes, such as dressing and green beans, don’t contain meat but aren’t vegetarian because they’re made with broth or bacon. Since your family members aren’t avoiding meat, they might not realize you can’t eat their dish until it’s too late. However, they might leave out these ingredients if you let them know ahead of time. You might say, "I really look forward to enjoying your cornbread dressing, but I know you make it with chicken broth. Do you think you could use vegetable broth instead so that I can eat it, too?" For example, dressing can be made with vegetable broth rather than chicken broth. Similarly, green beans taste delicious without bacon as an ingredient, plus they’re healthier! If your family loves the traditional recipe for their favorite side dishes, suggest having two versions of that dish. For example, you might have two versions of dressing and mashed potatoes. You might even send your relatives recipes for side dishes you can eat.

steps.headline: Bring a vegetarian dish to holiday gatherings.
steps.description: Make enough of your dish so everyone can have some. This way you’re still a part of the meal, rather than eating your own separate meal. Since you likely won’t be eating the main dish served by your host, cook one that you can eat. If you can, bring a side dish, as well. For example, you might bring tofurkey to Thanksgiving or lentil soup for Christmas. Vegetarian chili is also a great main dish. If you’re bringing a side dish, green bean casserole, mashed potatoes, roasted potatoes, and roasted cabbage are all common side dishes that are easily vegetarian. Bringing a vegetarian dish or two will also show your family that veg-friendly dishes are delicious, which might encourage them to add a few veggie dishes to the menu for the next holiday gathering.

steps.headline: Identify the vegetarian options before the meal is served.
steps.description:
Check with everyone who cooked to find out which dishes you can eat. Make sure to ask about specific ingredients, like broth, that they might not think of as meat. This way you can serve yourself along with everyone else without asking about every dish. You might say, “Wow, your dressing looks so delicious. Did you make it with vegetable or chicken broth?” or “Everything smells so good! Could you point out which dishes don’t contain meat so I know what to choose?”
If you’re also cutting out butter or milk, it’s especially important that you ask about these specific ingredients. These ingredients are easily overlooked if you’re not used to excluding them.

steps.headline: Keep the situation positive by not asking people to do extra work.
steps.description: Holidays are stressful for everyone, even people without food restrictions. If you come across as demanding, your family might have a negative reaction. Make it clear that you don’t expect everyone to change everything they’re doing or make a whole second menu to accommodate you. Let them know that you just want to be able to enjoy the meal with them. For instance, you wouldn’t say, “I’m vegetarian now, so can you make some extra dishes for me?” Instead, you might say, “Hey, I’m so excited about the holidays coming up, but I wanted to let you know I’m a vegetarian. I don’t expect you to go out of your way for me, but I hoped I’d be able to eat some of the side dishes.”

steps.headline: Decide if you’re willing to make meat dishes.
steps.description: Your family may expect you to cook meat dishes, and it’s okay to say, “No.” Whether or not you’re willing to cook meat will likely depend on your reasons for being a vegetarian. Don’t feel forced to do something that goes against your values. Some relatives might try to guilt you into serving meat, but that’s not okay. Say, “I respect your decision to eat meat, so I expect you to respect my decision not to eat it.”

steps.headline: Let your family know what the menu will be in advance.
steps.description: Tell them if you’ll be serving an entirely vegetarian meal, as well as dishes you plan to make. Not only will this avoid any surprises that might cause drama, it will also show your family that you have a delicious spread planned. You might say, "I'm planning to make vegetarian versions of our traditional dinner, so we'll have tofurkey, dressing, roasted vegetables, mashed potatoes, green bean casserole, sweet potato casserole, green beans, cranberry sauce, and pumpkin pie." This is especially helpful if some of your relatives are worried you won’t be serving their favorite dishes. You can show them there’s a yummy veg-friendly version of their traditional meal. If you do plan to serve a non-traditional meal, make sure your family understands that. You might even get them to join in on the theme. You might say, "This year we'll be doing an Italian theme, so I'm making a spinach lasagna and cheese ravioli. I'd like to invite all of you to bring your favorite dish, such as pizza or fettuccine alfredo."

steps.headline: Put a vegetarian twist on your family's traditional holiday dishes.
steps.description: For example, you might use vegetable broth and bits of tofurkey to make the rice dressing. This is the best way to get your family on-board with your vegetarian holiday meal. Look for tasty recipes online or in your favorite vegetarian cookbook. Many holiday recipes are already vegetarian or easily become vegetarian if you don't use bacon or ham as a topping or seasoning. For example, vegetable side dishes, mashed potatoes, sweet potato casserole, and pasta dishes are typically vegetarian. It’s easy to find veg-friendly recipes for all of your holiday favorites online.

steps.headline: Invite people to bring their favorite holiday dishes, if they desire.
steps.description: Doing the meal potluck-style will save you a lot of work and lets your family enjoy what they like. Although having an all-vegetarian holiday might sound great to you, your holiday feast will be more fun if everyone is happy. You might say, “I’m preparing lentil stew, roasted vegetables, mashed potatoes, cranberry sauce, bread, and pumpkin pie. You’re welcome to bring an extra dish, but it’s not expected.”

steps.headline: Avoid forcing people to eat an entirely vegetarian meal.
steps.description: While your values are very important to you, forcing people to give up their traditions isn’t going to make for a happy holiday. Remember, holiday meals are about enjoying time together as a family. Be open to compromising so everyone can enjoy the meal.

steps.headline: Stick to your vegetarian diet, even if people try to guilt you.
steps.description:
It’s likely some relatives will feel hurt that you won’t eat their dishes. However, you don’t owe it to anyone to sacrifice your values to make them happy. Stay true to who you are throughout the holidays. An easy way to deflect their comments is to say, “I’m sure it’s delicious, but I don’t eat that anymore. Someone will get to enjoy an extra helping!”
If you cave into the guilt, it’s likely they’ll continue to lay on the pressure every holiday because they know you’ll give in to it. However, they’ll eventually leave you alone if you stay strong.

steps.headline: Suggest a new holiday tradition that involves everyone.
steps.description:
Since many families built their traditions on food, changing your diet can interfere with your traditions. Starting a new one can help your family accept your decision more easily. Here are some ideas for ways you can make your holidays brighter:
Watch the Macy’s Thanksgiving Day parade together. Take an after-dinner walk. Play a sport as a family. Make a holiday craft together. Watch a movie together. Do a holiday-themed puzzle. Volunteer at a soup kitchen. Decorate a special Christmas tree together. Bake holiday cookies as a family. Make cocoa and go look at Christmas lights.

steps.headline: Express gratitude for everyone’s efforts to encourage a positive tone.
steps.description: It’s normal for non-vegetarians to feel attacked by your choice to avoid meat. You can relieve that tension by thanking people for putting effort into the meal. Plus, being grateful helps you feel better, too. Say, “I can see how much work people put into making this meal. I’m so grateful to have a family that cares about each other this much.”

steps.headline: Choose a seat that’s far away from the turkey or meat entree.
steps.description: Sitting next to a meat dish isn’t fun for a vegetarian, so it’s a good idea to find a seat far away from the meat. Sit on the opposite side of the table to minimize the sight and smell of the meat. It helps to ask the host to save you a seat away from the meat. You can always point out that’s it’s more convenient for the meat-eating guests. Say, “Why don’t you guys sit over here so you can easily reach the turkey. I’d like to sit over there since I won’t be having any.”

steps.headline: Keep your thoughts about vegetarianism to yourself during the holidays.
steps.description: It’s likely your vegetarian beliefs are important to you, but holiday dinners aren’t the right time to advocate for your cause. You’ll enjoy your holidays a lot more if you keep your opinions to yourself. Instead, talk about positive topics you know won’t lead to controversy. If you feel like someone is attacking your choices, excuse yourself from the conversation. You might spark a conversation with someone else, go get another helping of your favorite dish, refill your drink, or take a quick break in the bathroom. Although defending yourself will be tempting, fighting during the holidays will make you feel worse in the long run.

steps.headline: Answer questions about your vegetarianism politely.
steps.description: It’s likely at least one person is going to ask you about your choice to be a vegetarian. Acknowledge what they said, then steer the conversation back to something else. You might say, “Being a vegetarian is really important to me, thanks for asking. Is this cranberry sauce the one you made? It’s delicious!”

steps.headline: Find an ally if your family isn’t tolerant of your values.
steps.description: Your family may struggle to accept your choices, but that doesn’t mean your holiday has to be miserable. When things get tough, turn to a relative who is always supportive of you. If you can’t find an ally within your family, plan to text a vegetarian friend or post on a support forum if things get rough. Over time, it’s likely your family will become more accepting of your choices, so don’t give up.
